docs.text: Jarvis-HEP (Just a Robust and Versatile Interface Suite for High Energy) is a Python project to deploy parameter scan, packages link and data visulization.

docs.title: Note
docs.text: Jarvis-HEP is a User demand driven project. If you encounter any bugs or unexpected behaviour and/or any functional requests, you are encouraged to report a bug and/or to write down your needs in our Github Issues pages.

docs.title: License
docs.text: All Jarvis-HEP Tools (including Jarvis-HEP and Jarvis-PLOT) are released under the MIT license. The generated output code of Jarvis-HEP can be freely used according to the MIT license, but as they rely on other (PyPI) released libraries also their License has to be taken into account.

docs.title: Installation
docs.text:
Jarvis-HEP is a pure Python project. No compilation is required, and no system-level dependencies are enforced by default.

In practice, installing Jarvis-HEP only involves:

  1. Downloading the source code

  2. Installing the required Python dependencies

  3. Running it directly

docs.title: Requirements
docs.text:
• Python ≥ 3.10 (newest Python version prefered)
  • Any Python 3 environment is acceptable, including the system Python, provided that package installation permissions are available. Using an isolated environment (venv, conda, or pyenv) is recommended but not required.

Jarvis-HEP does not rely on any graphical backend and can be safely used on servers, clusters, and other headless environments.

docs.title: Clone the repository from GitHub:
docs.text:
git clone https://github.com/pengxuan-zhu-phys/Jarvis-HEP.git
cd Jarvis-HEP

You may also download the source archive manually if preferred.

docs.title: Downloading a Released Version (Recommended)
docs.text:
In addition to cloning the development repository, Jarvis-HEP provides stable released versions.

Released versions are recommended for users who prefer a fixed and well-tested snapshot of the code.

You can download a released source archive from the GitHub Releases page:

  • Navigate to the Releases section of the repository
  • Download the corresponding .zip or .tar.gz source archive
  • Extract it and enter the project directory

This installation guide applies equally to both the development version (cloned from Git) and released source archives.

docs.title: Installing Dependencies
docs.text:
All required Python dependencies are listed in requirements.txt.

python -m pip install -r requirements.txt

It is also recommended to install them inside a virtual environment. Below we show a minimal and reproducible setup using pyenv. Other environment managers can be used equivalently.

docs.title: Using pyenv (optional): example with Python 3.10.12
docs.text:
The version number 3.10.12 is used here as an example. Any newer Python 3.x version compatible with the listed dependencies can be used instead.

pyenv install 3.10.12
pyenv virtualenv 3.10.12 jarvis
pyenv activate jarvis
pip install -r requirements.txt

docs.title: Running Jarvis-HEP
docs.text:
Jarvis-HEP does not require a formal installation step.

Once the dependencies are installed, it can be executed directly from the source directory:

Jarvis ./bin/EggBox/Example_Bridson.yaml

To run the EggBox example, which is detailed explained in the next page.

Alternatively, Jarvis-HEP can be imported and used as a Python module in custom scripts.

docs.title: External Physics Tools
docs.text:
Jarvis-HEP serves as a workflow and sampling engine.

External physics packages (such as spectrum generators, event generators, or likelihood codes) are not bundled and should be installed separately according to the requirements of each analysis.

Please refer to the corresponding tutorials for concrete examples.

docs.title: Common Issues
docs.text:
• Missing dependencies Ensure all packages listed in requirements.txt are installed in the active Python environment.

  • Multiple Python versions Verify that python and pip refer to the same environment: bash which python which pip

docs.title: Tutorial: Declarative Scanning with a 2D Eggbox Example
docs.text:
This tutorial uses Example_Bridson.yaml as a working example.

The point is not the Eggbox model. The point is how to describe a scan in Jarvis-HEP.

If you can follow this example, you can adapt Jarvis-HEP to other problems.

docs.title: The Problem Pattern
docs.text:
To study a Beyond Standard Model numerically, one typically needs to scan its parameter space. Most scan problems look like this:

  • Pick some parameters
  • Explore their values with a sampler
  • Run an external program at each point
  • Save the results

Jarvis-HEP is built for this pattern.

docs.title: Eggbox Function as an Simplifed Package
docs.text:
We begin with the Eggbox function, a purely mathematical function.

The Eggbox function here is defined as a two-dimensional function of two real variables, denoted by x and y.

z(x, y) = (sin(x) * cos(y) + 2)^5

For each input point (x, y), the function returns a single scalar value z. In a realistic physics study, z could represent any theoretical prediction or observable, for example the Higgs boson mass in the MSSM. Without a numerical scan, it is hard to see how such an observable behaves across the parameter space.

As shown in the above figure, a three-dimensional surface plot of z(xx, yy) clearly illustrates this structure. This function has several characteristic features: - It is smooth and continuous - It exhibits a highly structured, multi-peak landscape - Many local maxima and minima appear across the parameter space

These features make the Eggbox function a standard test case for sampling algorithms and scanning workflows.

Suppose an experiment measures this observable as

z = 100 ± 10.

Our task is then to identify which regions in the (x, y) parameter space are compatible with this measurement.

To make this numerical study practical, we implement a small package that computes z for any given (x, y).

docs.title: EggBox package （Code see eggbox）
docs.text:
We now move from the mathematical description to the computational abstraction used by Jarvis-HEP.

In Jarvis-HEP, an input point refers to one complete set of parameter values. For the Eggbox example, one input point is the pair (xx, yy).

The Eggbox calculation is not treated as a direct function call. Instead, it is packaged as a small external program, referred to as a calculator.

The calculator follows a strict input–output contract:

  1. Jarvis-HEP writes the current input point to input.json
  2. Jarvis-HEP executes the calculator program
  3. The calculator reads input.json and computes the Eggbox value
  4. The calculator writes results to output.json
  5. Jarvis-HEP reads output.json and records the requested outputs

In this example, the calculator writes: - z: the value of the Eggbox function - Time: a dummy field used to mimic runtime information

From Jarvis-HEP’s perspective, the calculator is a complete black box. Jarvis-HEP does not inspect the internal code or the mathematical expression.

This example demonstrates the core abstraction used by Jarvis-HEP: any function or model can be used, as long as it can be packaged as a program with well-defined inputs and outputs.

docs.title: How Jarvis-HEP Models the Problem
docs.text:
Jarvis-HEP splits the task into parts:

  • Sampling: which points to try
  • Calculation: what to run at each point
  • Workflow: how everything is connected and executed

You do not write scripts to glue these together. You declare them in YAML.

See: - Guide to YAML

docs.title: Step 1: Name the Scan and Outputs
docs.text:
Open Example_Bridson.yaml.

The Scan section does basic setup: - A scan name - Output paths - Bookkeeping info

This section does not change physics or algorithms.

See: - Scan

docs.title: Step 2: Choose a Sampling Method
docs.text:
The Sampling section answers two questions: - Which sampler is used? - Which variables are sampled?

In this example: - The sampler is Bridson - Two variables are defined - Each variable has bounds

Jarvis-HEP uses this to generate points. Nothing is executed yet.

See: - Sampling

docs.title: Step 3: Set Sampler Controls
docs.text:
Some samplers need extra settings.

In Example_Bridson.yaml these include: - A radius - A limit on attempts

These settings affect how points are proposed. They do not affect calculations.

docs.title: Step 4: Declare the Calculation
docs.text:
The Calculators section describes an external program.

Jarvis-HEP treats it as a black box.

You declare: - How inputs are prepared - How the program is run - Where outputs are read from

Jarvis-HEP handles: - Working directories - Execution order - Parallel runs

No glue scripts are needed.

See: - Calculators

docs.title: Step 5: Connect Inputs and Outputs
docs.text:
Inside Calculators, mappings are defined.

These mappings say: - Which sampled variables go to which inputs - Which files or values are read as outputs

This is the only place where sampling meets calculation.

docs.title: Step 6: Check the Environment
docs.text:
The EnvReqs section lists requirements: - Supported systems - Required tools or libraries

Jarvis-HEP checks these before running.

See: - EnvReqs

docs.title: Step 7: Optional Utilities
docs.text:
The Utils section defines shared helpers.

Examples: - Tables - Interpolations - Reusable data

These helpers do not control sampling or execution.

See: - Utils

docs.title: What Jarvis-HEP Does Automatically
docs.text:
From one YAML file, Jarvis-HEP will: - Build the workflow - Generate sampling points - Run the external program - Collect outputs - Save results in a fixed layout

You do not manage loops or job control.

docs.title: Adapting This to Your Own Problem
docs.text:
To use Jarvis-HEP for a new task:

  1. List the parameters you want to scan
  2. Pick a sampling method
  3. Treat your code as a black box
  4. Declare inputs and outputs in YAML
  5. Run Jarvis-HEP

If your task fits this list, it fits Jarvis-HEP.

docs.title: Practical Introduction to YAML Format
docs.text:
Author: Pengxuan Zhu

This document provides a short, practical introduction to YAML for users who are not familiar with the format. This document assumes no prior knowledge of YAML. It is intended to help you read and write YAML files correctly before using them to configure Jarvis-HEP.

YAML is a human-readable data-serialization format commonly used for configuration files.

docs.title: What Is YAML?
docs.text:
YAML stands for “YAML Ain’t Markup Language”. It is designed to be:

  • Easy to read and write
  • Indentation-based
  • Friendly to version control systems

YAML is often used as an alternative to JSON or XML for configuration purposes.

docs.title: 1. Indentation Matters
docs.text:
YAML uses indentation to represent structure. Spaces define hierarchy.

  • Use spaces, not tabs
  • Be consistent (commonly 2 or 4 spaces)

Correct

parent:
  child:
    key: value

Incorrect

parent:
 child:
    key: value

docs.title: 2. Key–Value Pairs
docs.text:
A basic YAML element is a key–value pair:

key: value

Keys are strings. Values can be strings, numbers, booleans, lists, or mappings.

docs.title: 3. Lists
docs.text:
Lists are written using hyphens (-), equivalent to the List object in Python: 

items:
  - apple
  - orange
  - banana

Lists of mappings are also common, equivalent to the Dict object in Python:

users:
  - name: Alice
    role: admin
  - name: Bob
    role: user

docs.title: 4. Strings and Quoting
docs.text:
Most strings do not require quotes.

name: example
path: /tmp/data

Use quotes when: - The string contains special characters - The value could be misinterpreted

expression: "a > b"
version: "1.0"

docs.title: 5. Numbers and Booleans
docs.text:
YAML automatically interprets numbers and booleans.

count: 10
ratio: 0.5
enabled: true
disabled: false

Avoid quoting numbers unless they must be treated as strings.

docs.title: 6. Comments
docs.text:
Comments start with #.

# This is a comment
key: value  # Inline comment

Comments are ignored by the parser.

docs.title: ❌ Using Tabs
docs.text:
key:
\tchild: value

Tabs are not allowed. Always use spaces.

docs.title: ❌ Inconsistent Indentation
docs.text:
key:
  child1: value
   child2: value

Even a single extra space changes the structure.

docs.title: ❌ Missing Spaces After Colon
docs.text:
key:value

Correct form:

key: value

docs.title: ❌ Ambiguous Values
docs.text:
yes: no
on: off

These may be interpreted as booleans in YAML 1.1. Use explicit values or quotes if unsure.

docs.title: Anchors and Aliases
docs.text:
YAML supports reusable blocks using anchors (&) and aliases (*).

defaults: &defaults
  timeout: 10
  retries: 3

task1:
  <<: *defaults
  name: task_one

This reduces duplication in large configuration files.

docs.title: How to Validate YAML
docs.text:
Before using a YAML file, it is strongly recommended to validate it.

Options include: - Online validators (e.g. yamllint) - Command-line tools - Parsing the file in Python using yaml.safe_load

docs.title: Recommended References
docs.text:

docs.title: Summary
docs.text:
• YAML is indentation-based and human-readable
  • Consistent spacing is critical
  • Start simple and validate often
  • When in doubt, prefer clarity over brevity

Now, you can proceed to the Jarvis-HEP tutorial.
